title: 115_s3686
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Student Athletes from Concussions Act of 2018" and includes minimum state requirements. Each State receiving funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 must establish minimum requirements for concussion safety and management plans in local educational agencies within five years of the Act's enactment. The text chunk discusses training school personnel on concussion safety and management, including prevention, recognition, and response to concussions. It also mentions using appropriate forms for reporting and record-keeping, treatment plans, and prevention strategies for students and parents. The curr_chunk discusses supporting students recovering from concussions, including resuming athletic and academic activities with a concussion management team. The curr_chunk focuses on providing academic accommodations and overseeing the recovery of students with concussions, emphasizing the use of best practices for safety standards and management. The curr_chunk emphasizes disseminating concussion safety information and applying best practice standards in public schools. Information based on scientific evidence must be posted on school grounds and websites. The curr_chunk focuses on providing information about concussions to students, including the risks, actions to take, signs and symptoms, definition of a concussion, ways to reduce incidence, and effects on academic performance. The curr_chunk emphasizes the immediate response to a suspected concussion in school-sponsored athletic activities, including removing the student from participation and prohibiting their return on the same day. The designated individual must report any information about a student's injury, including the date, time, and type of injury, to the parent or guardian. If a student sustains a concussion, regardless of where or how it occurred, they cannot return to athletics until cleared. Before resuming school-sponsored athletic activities, a student must have written clearance from a healthcare professional stating their capability to participate. The plan for recovery should include periods of rest and gradual reintroduction of cognitive and physical demands. If a State fails to comply with concussion guidelines, funding under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 will be reduced by 5% for the first year and 10% for succeeding years. Notification of noncompliance will be given before any reductions are made. The Secretary of Education must notify the State and Congress before reducing funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 for noncompliance with concussion guidelines. SEC. 3. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not impact civil or criminal liability under Federal or State law. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "concussion" is defined as a mild traumatic brain injury caused by a blow, jolt, or motion to the head or body that disrupts normal brain functioning and alters the mental state of the individual. This includes symptoms such as confusion, disorientation, impaired consciousness, memory dysfunction, or loss of consciousness. A concussion is defined as a mild traumatic brain injury that can result in loss of consciousness lasting less than 30 minutes or various symptoms like physical, cognitive, emotional, or difficulty sleeping. It can occur with or without loss of consciousness during participation in sports or recreational activities. Health care professionals trained in diagnosing and managing traumatic brain injuries in children include physicians and certified athletic trainers recognized by the state. Local educational agencies and states are defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Related services personnel are individuals who provide related services. "Related services personnel are individuals who provide services as defined under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. School-sponsored athletic activity includes physical education classes, non-instructional athletic activities on school grounds, extracurricular sports teams, and recess activities."
